page.title: 18VILLAGE HISTORY CONT
page.content: CASTLE MARKET BUT THE LARGE GREENS PROVED INVITING AND THEY OFTEN STOPPED TO GRAZE. LOCAL WOMEN WOULD FLAP THEIR LARGE WHITE APRONS TO FRIGHTEN THEM AWAY. A PEDLAR, MR BRADLEY, SOLD POTS AND PANS AGAIN BY HORSE AND CART. IN THE HERRING SEASON, THE "CALLER HERRIN" MAN WOULD COLLECT A BARREL OF FRESH FISH FROM WINSTON STATION AND SELL THEM, FRESH AND SHINY, FOR A SHILLING FOR A PLATEFUL. SUNDAY WAS A DAY WHEN ANY KIND OF WORK WAS FROWNED UPON, MOST PEOPLE ATTENDING EITHER CHURCH OR CHAPEL. AS WELL AS THE PARISH CHURCH THERE WERE THREE CHAPELS AND THE FRIENDS MEETING HOUSE. BEFORE A REGULAR BUS SERVICE WAS ESTABLISHED, AN OLD BUS RUN BY BUCKLES WENT TO DARLINGTON ON MONDAY, MARKET DAY. AT THAT TIME THERE WAS A GREAT VARIETY OF SHOPS IN THE VILLAGE.
